typeData.textContent:
This psychology course will introduce you to some of the major research areas within the field of psychology: the scientific study of behaviour.  The course begins with an overview of psychology and its research methods, and then covers several fundamental topics in psychology such as biological psychology, learning and memory, and conscious states.

This section of PSYC101 is a 3-credit online distance education course.  It has both synchronous (live; e.g., Q&A sessions, discussion sessions, and group activities) and asynchronous  components (not live; e.g., prerecorded lectures, online quizzes, and self-assessments).  Because it is a distance education course, most course-related activities are asynchronous.

The course uses an open-source text that is supplemented by many video-based lectures and online resources. In addition, the course contains interviews with some leading research psychologists and some educational animations.

There are no prerequisites or corequisites for this course.  Note that you cannot receive credit for both PSYC101 and PSYC100.

nodes.title: 10 Fun Facts about Neural Transmission (Li Nan Qiu)
nodes.description: some interesting statistics about neurons and neural transmission in humans and other animals.

typeData.textContent:
1. there is ~100 billion neurons in the human brain, and ~300 million neurons in the octopus brain.

2. A signal transmitted through a neuron travels at 1.2 to 250 miles/hour.

3. The number of ways information can travel inside our brain surpasses the number of stars in the universe. 

4. Although neurons have the longest lifespan among cells in our body, large numbers of neurons die during differentiation and migration. 

5. neurons create and send out more messages than all the phones in the world combined. 

6. Neurons multiply at the rate of 250,000/minute during early pregnancy.

7. The length of a giraffe's primary afferent axon (from neck to toe) is 15 feet long. 

8. If we lined up all the neurons in our body, each about 10 microns long, the line would reach 600 miles in length. 

9. An average 20 year old man has around 109,000 miles of myelinated axons inside his brain.

10. There are 1,000-10,000 synapses in a typical neuron.

nodes.title: EPSP and IPSP (Li Nan Qiu)
nodes.description: Some information about EPSPs and IPSPs to help you study for week 6.

typeData.textContent:
An excitatory postsynaptic potential (EPSP) beings the neuron potential -55 mV closer to its firing threshold. The membrane is depolarized from a net gain of positive charge, and the potential comes close to zero. 

An inhibitory postsynaptic potential (IPSP) changes the membrane charge so that it becomes further from the firing threshold. There is a net gain of negative charge and the potential moves further away from zero in a process known as hyperpolarization. 

EPSPs and IPSPs are transient changes in potential. EPSP from the release of a transmitter at a synapse is usually too small to trigger spikes inside the postsynaptic neuron. But the combined input from hundreds or thousands of other neurons can result in large fluctuations of membrane potential. When sufficiently depolarized, an action potential occurs.

Good Research and the Disadvantages of Peer Review (Cole Stevens)

typeData.textContent:
When a researcher performs an experiment, they are typically working towards publishing their results. Researchers may be inclined to publish their results for many reasons: they may want to allow room for others to expand on their research, be credited for their discoveries, attain sponsors or research grants, or purely for the advancement of scientific knowledge. It is important however, that the research conducted is of high quality because inadequate research may create misleading information that could hamper other scientists, organizations, and the general public. To counter this, the majority of scientific studies undergo peer review, where other experts in the subject matter provide feedback. Section 2.3 of the textbook talks about the many advantages of peer review, but the following paragraph will counter this by highlighting the many disadvantages to consider as well.

Peer review has many disadvantages associated with it that must be taken into consideration. The peer review process takes time, thereby causing a delay in the spread of information. It also consumes the time of the peer-reviewer, who may become delayed in their own research. Papers that undergo the peer review process can be subject to the peer reviewers biases, such as through homophily by gender which stems from researchers tending to favour the research of peers from the same gender (Helmer, Schottdorf, Neef, & Battaglia, 2017). Traditionally, peer reviews are conducted with a single blind, where the peer reviewers remain anonymous but the author’s identity is revealed, which can lead to the reviewers providing biased feedback against the author. Double blind peer reviews are also used, but often scientific communities are so small the reviewers can identify the author based on the subject or writing style (Kelt, n.d.). Peer reviewers are often considered “gate-keepers” because they help determine whether research is good enough to be published. This is important because poor performance by peer reviewers may lead to low-quality research being published or high quality research being rejected. 

Sources

Helmer, M., Schottdorf, M., Neef, A., & Battaglia, D. (2017). Author response: Gender bias in scholarly peer review. doi:10.7554/elife.21718.012

Kelt, M. (n.d.). Advantages and disadvantages of peer review. Retrieved June 18, 2020, from https://www.gcu.ac.uk/library/pilot/publication/peerreview/advantagesanddisadvantages/

nodes.title: Scenarios: Sympathetic or Parasympathetic nervous system? [Brainz - Justin]

typeData.textContent:
The course textbook (Spielman, 2017) discusses the placebo effect when talking about ways to control for differences between participants. In a standard randomly controlled trial (RCT), one group of participants receives experimental intervention, while the other receives an indistinguishable placebo control (Annoni, 2018, p. 476). This is most commonly used when testing effects of a medication, to ensure any differences measured are due to what is being tested, which preserves a trial’s internal validity (Speilman, 2017, p. 54).

However, there has long been debate over the ethics of placebos and placebo effects in clinical research, which the TED-Ed video only briefly mentions (Annoni 2018, p. 463). While many support placebo-controlled trials, it is still debated whether it is ethical to use placebos over active controls (Annoni 2018, p. 481).

In the last 50 years, the double-blind, placebo-controlled RCT has been widely renowned as the “gold-standard” of clinical research (Annoni 2018, p. 477). In contrast, Annoni (2018) discusses the RCT dilemma, which addresses the conflict between clinical research and clinical practice: the best way to test the effectiveness of a treatment may not be the best way to treat a participant’s condition (Annoni 2018). Deception is objectionable on the grounds that it limits participant autonomy and can breach researcher-participant trust, but when placebos are prescribed within appropriate ethical limits, Foddy (2009) argues that these grounds do not apply (p. 4). Perhaps one of the most well known examples of deception in research is the Tuskegee experiment, where the control group was left untreated despite the fact that penicillin was named an effective treatment for syphilis during the course of the experiment (Foddy, 2009, 8). Doctors should only provide placebos, argues Foddy (2019), when there is no better treatment or therapy that the patient is willing to take (p. 9).

Critics of placebo-controlled trials favour the use of active-controlled trials (ACTs) instead, where the control group receives an already proven effective treatment which is tested against an experimental treatment (Annoni 2018, 477).

Sources:
Annoni, M. (2018). Chapter Eighteen – The Ethics of Placebo Effects in Clinical Practice and Research. International Review of Neurobiology; 139, 463-484
Foddy, B. (2009) A Duty to Deceive: Placebos in Clinical Practice, The American Journal of Bioethics, 9:12, 4-12, DOI: 10.1080/15265160903318350
Spielman, R. M. (2017). Psychology. Houston, Texas 77005: OpenStax.

nodes.title: Summary Information (Grace Logel)
nodes.description: This node contains a summary of all the information covered pertaining to the 4 lobes of the brain from the video and the crossword in the surrounding nodes.

typeData.textContent:
There are 4 lobes located within the brain...

1. Frontal Lobe: located in the front/anterior portion of the brain and involved in reasoning, motor control, emotion and language due to 3 regions found within the lobe
A. Motor Cortex involved in planning and coordinating movement
B. Prefrontal Lobe involved in higher-level cognition like judgement, reasoning and impulse
C. Broca’s Area involved in language production

2. Parietal Lobe: located posterior/behind the frontal lobe and involved in processing the body’s senses
A. Somatosensory cortex that is essential for processing sensory information across the body 
I. Topographical: a spatial relationship is maintained on the surface of the cortex

3. Temporal Lobe: located directly under/inferior to the parietal lobe and involved in hearing, memory, emotion and some aspects of language due to 2 regions found within the lobe
A. Auditory Cortex involved in processing auditory information
B. Wernicke’s Area involved in speech comprehension

4. Occipital Lobe: located directly in the back of the brain and involved in interpreting incoming visual information due to the primary visual cortex
A. Retinotopic: a close relationship between the position of an object in the visual field and the position represented on the cortex

The Pancreas and Diabetes (Peri Sheppard)
nodes.description: A summary of Diabetes and it's relation to the endocrine system

typeData.textContent:
The pancreas secretes insulin and glucagon, hormones essential for stabilizing blood sugar. Insulin works to bring blood glucose levels down and glucagon works to raise them, when needed.  Insulin and glucagon are protein and peptide hormones respectively, meaning they are composed of chain(s) of amino acids. These pancreatic hormones are examples of hormones that are released as a result of a non-hormonal chemical because their release is triggered by glucose concentration, not another hormone or directly from the nervous system. The release of insulin is controlled by the autonomic nervous system, thus normal individuals don't have to actively monitor their blood glucose levels; Their bodies just do it for them. 

Diabetes is the resulting condition of the pancreas not producing enough insulin to maintain a normal blood sugar level, therefore individuals with diabetes have to inject themselves with insulin manually and actively monitor their blood sugar levels.

nodes.title: Week 7 Robert Tryon's Experiment Quiz (Carlos Li)
Week 7 Thoughts on Genes vs Exnvironment (Carlos Li)

typeData.textContent:
This week’s content was more focussed towards human genetics and behaviour. After having several weeks of content that I had already previously learned about, I was refreshed to see a topic in which I haven’t had much prior exposure to. In fact, before starting this week's material, I always thought that genes were the main factor in determining one's behaviour. 
I used to believe in the range of reaction theory, in which genes would set a boundary for a behaviour's potential and that it was up to the person to determine how far they would take that potential. Throughout my life, whenever I saw someone excel at a certain behaviour, I always thought that they had a genetic advantage. For example, when seeing a group of people running, I would always think that the fastest person had a genetic advantage over the other runners. At the same time, I also believed that that faster person also had to work hard to fulfill the potential given to him by his genetic makeup. 
When learning about Robert Tryon's experiment with maze running mice, I furthered my belief in the range of reaction theory. Robert Tryon attempted to contrast the view that behaviour develops through learning. What he did was selectively breed mice and measure their abilities to complete a maze. He mated the best females with the best males and the worst females with the worst males. By doing so, he was able to compare strong genetic makeups against weaker genetic makeups. At the same time, he repeated this process for twenty-one generations and by the eighth he noticed that there wasn't much of an overlap in abilities. From his experiment, it can be concluded that genes influence behaviour. However, it also doesn’t rule out the fact that the environment may also contribute to the development of behaviour.
Later on, I learned that genes weren't the only factor in determining behaviour and that environment also played a role. In addition to this, this week's content also taught me that it's hard to ask whether genes or the environment plays a larger role in behaviour. It shifted me into focusing more on how much either factor plays in the development of behaviour.

nodes.title: Cells of the Nervous System - Yilian Zhao

typeData.textContent:
There are two types of cells that make up the Central Nervous system, called glia and neurons. Neurons are the main information processors, connected in order to perform all of the required actions for the nervous system to function. Glial cells function in a supportive role to neurons, insulating them by forming a myelin sheath, helping them connect properly, and disposing of waste products (Spielman, 2017, p. 80). There are multiple parts to a neuron; the soma has extensions called dendrites and contains the nucleus, the axon extends the soma to the terminal buttons, which have synaptic vesicles that contain neurotransmitters that are often released to receptors on other neurons. 

The synapse is the space between neurons into which the synaptic vesicles release neurotransmitters once the signal reaches the terminal buttons. The neurotransmitters bind to receptors on the other neuron, which they recognize due to the specific fit of a lock and key model (Spielman, 2017, p. 81). That is, the incorrect neurotransmitters cannot bind to certain receptors. Neurons are able to operate due to their semipermeable membrane, which allows certain ions to pass through and build up a difference in charge, which is then used to transmit signals. 

The imbalance in charge on either side of the membrane provides the energy for the signal to occur, which happens when neurotransmitter receptors receive their corresponding neurotransmitters and small pores open in the membrane of the neuron. These gates allow Na+ to come into the cell propelled by the concentration gradient since at resting state or resting potential, there is a buildup of more Na+ ions outside the cell, and more K+ ions inside the neuron (Spielman, 2017, p. 83). Once the pores open and Na+ flows in, the cells become more and more positive, and if the charge reaches the threshold of excitation, the action potential is able to commence, where sodium potassium pumps begin working to move K+ out of the cell and repolarize the cell to the original resting state. This signal is propelled from neuron to neuron until it reaches its destination. The way neurons communicate with each other is an electrochemical event, where the action potential going down an axon is electrical and the neurotransmitters travelling across the synapse is chemical.

nodes.title: The Endocrine System: An Introduction (Leela Moza)

typeData.textContent:
Our brain is made up of many gyri and sulci that help increase its surface area. This is what gives the human its characteristically convoluted folds. But, what happens when these folds do not develop properly?

Though lissencephaly is common in animals such as rats, it is not often found in humans. Lissencephaly is a rare brain disorder in infants that causes the brain to be abnormally smooth. Gyri and sulci do not develop due to mutations causing neuron and glial cells to travel to wrong locations in the brain during cell specialization in the fetus (Chen & Gleeson 2018). Lissencephaly can be severe; many infants with this condition have impaired motor and cognitive abilities as well as frequent seizures. Though there is no cure for lissencephaly, therapy can be done to support the patient's quality of life and drugs can be administered to control symptoms, such as anticonvulsants to reduce the fequency of seizures (Chen & Gleeson 2018). Since this disorder is so rare, many patients of lissencephaly are the subjects of case studies and clinical trials.

There are many complications to patients with lissencephaly. A case study was performed on a newborn that was having seizures just hours after being delivered. They had unusual posturing, which indicated to doctors that the newborn had some form of brain damage, and difficulty breathing as a result of their hypoxia. An MRI scan was conducted and the infant's lissencephaly was confirmed when the image displayed that absence of folds within the brain. The abnormally smooth cerebral cortex was also accompanied by a thin corpus callosum, which was another characteristic of lissencephaly. The patient was given antibiotic therapy and was eventually discharged from the hospital since all their other systems were functioning properly. Though there are many different types of treatments, the life expectancy of a lissencephalic patient is around 4 years (Alhasan et al. 2015).

References

Chen, D., & Gleeson, J. G. (2018, January 10). Lissencephaly. Retrieved July 02, 2020, from https://rarediseases.org/rare-diseases/lissencephaly/

Alhasan, M., Mathkour, M., & Milburn, J. (2015). Clinical Images: Postterm Newborn with Lissencephaly Presented with Seizure: Case Report and Review of Literature. Retrieved July 02, 2020, from https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4482552/

nodes.title: The Divisions of the Nervous System (Jessica Groening)
nodes.description: This is a summary of the divisions of the nervous system with some relatable examples.

typeData.textContent:
The nervous system: a complex system found in many organisms that is responsible for coordinating the functions of the body and reacting to the different stimuli within the environment. 

1st division (CNS/PNS): The two major divisions are known as the central nervous system (CNS) and the peripheral nervous system (PNS). These two divisions have been separated according to their major working locations in the body, though they both work together to achieve the common goal of managing the body’s various activities. 
a) The central nervous system (CNS) is contained in the brain and spinal cord. The brain is a very complex organ composed of billions of nervous system cells. It receives signals we call synapses from the body, and then, it processes the information by interacting with the many specialized areas within it. Finally, the brain will release more synapses to instruct the body about its chosen response. The brain is very similar to a computer in that it uses many mechanisms to receive, process, and transmit information. 
b) The peripheral nervous system is found in the rest of the body and it connects the organs and other structures of the body to the central nervous system.

2nd division (SNS/ANS): The peripheral nervous system (PNS) is divided into the somatic nervous system (SNS) and the autonomic nervous system (ANS). 
c) The somatic nervous system allows the body to exhibit voluntary controls and it interacts directly with the external environment. This system will carry sensory signals from the body to the brain with sensory neurons. These are also called AFFERENT fibers because they ARRIVE at the CNS. Additionally, there are motor neurons that carry motor signals from the brain to the body. These are also called EFFERENT fibers because they EXIT the CNS. The somatic nervous system provides us with the ability to learn new skills. For example, rock climbing; in order to climb to the top of the wall, you need to feel the areas on the rock with the best grips and, you need to move your arms and legs to climb up. 
d) The other division of the peripheral nervous system is the autonomic nervous system. You can think of this division as AUTOMATIC because that is essentially its purpose. It is responsible for involuntarily controlling the body’s internal organs and glands. This is a system that does not require conscious thought, though it is essential for the body’s survival. For example, the autonomic nervous system controls the release of digestive enzymes so that the giant hamburger you just ate can be broken down into a smaller form of protein that the body can use.

3rd division (SNS/PNS): The autonomic nervous system can be further subdivided into the sympathetic nervous system and the parasympathetic nervous system. These divisions act simultaneously with an ever changing balance between them. 
e) The sympathetic nervous system is involved in the stress response and allows the body to assemble energy stores to be used in life threatening circumstances. For example, the sympathetic nervous system will be amplified when you encounter an angry bear in the wild. The body will perceive the bear as a great threat and prepare itself to either fight or run way. This survival instinct is known as the fight or flight response. The physiological changes that will occur in the body during this response include dilated pupils, salivation inhibition, increased heart rate, dilated bronchi, digestion inhibition, and inhibiting the contraction of the bladder. All these changes attempt to increase the chances of survival. For example, the pupils become dilated so that the organism can easily see the threat or point of safety. 
f) In contrast, the parasympathetic nervous system is the energy-saver. It is responsible for returning the body to routine activities. The physiological manifestations include constricted pupils, salivation stimulation, slowed heart rate, constricted bronchi, digestion stimulation, and contraction of the bladder. The parasympathetic nervous system has sometimes been called the ‘rest and digest’ phase. This is a fairly accurate description because it is with this system that the body will be relaxed and focus on consuming and storing energy resources.

typeData.textContent:
MIDBRAIN: 
The midbrain is a division of the brain located between the forebrain and the hindbrain, consisting of 3 parts which include the tegmentum and tectum. In mammals, the tectum is composed of 2 pairs of bumps, known as the inferior colliculi and the superior colliculi. The tegmentum contains multiple structures such as the reticular formation, fibers of passage, periaqueductal grey, substantia nigra, red nucleus, and the ventral tegmental area. Out of all of them, we will be focusing on the following 3:

1. Reticular formation 
The reticular formation is very important in regulating one’s sleep/wake cycle, arousal, alertness and motor activity. It is centered in the midbrain, but also extends up into the forebrain and down into the hindbrain. 

2. Substantia nigra
Substantia nigra is the origin of dopamine production and is involved in control of movement. 

3. Ventral tegmental area 
The ventral tegmental area is also known to be where dopamine is produced. It is also associated with mood, reward and addiction. 

HINDBRAIN:
As a division of the brain which contains the medulla, pons, and the cerebellum, the hindbrain is located at the back of the head, which looks like an extension of the spinal cord. 

1. Medulla 
The medulla controls automated processes, such as breathing, blood pressure, and heart rate. It is involved in maintaining the homeostasis of the body. 

2. Pons 
The pons is a large bulge which consists of fibres and pontine nuclei, and connects the brain and the spinal cord. It is also involved in regulating brain activity during sleep. The medulla, pons, and the midbrain forms a structure known as the brainstem. 

3. Cerebellum
The cerebellum is a structure which takes up only 10% of the brain’s volume but contains about 50% of all of its neurons. It controls balance, coordination, movement, and motor skills. It is thought to be associated with procedural memory, which is a memory involved in learning and remembering how to perform tasks.

Welcome to Afreud's Week 5 Tapestry on the Human Endocrine System:

We decided to focus on the physiological and psychological processes of the Endocrine System and how the hormones affect our emotions and reactions. 
To consider this topic in-depth we decided to look at how chronic alcohol consumption can lead to several hormonal imbalances and negatively affect this endocrine system.

The Endocrine System and its Effect on Emotions (Ishaan Sareen)- Looking at the psychological aspect of the Endocrine System and how it has a large impact on our emotions and behavior in different environments.

nodes.description: Use this reflection question to test your understanding of the resting membrane potential.

typeData.textContent:
Why is the resting membrane potential negative?

Answer: The concentration gradient in which there are more negative ions inside the cell and more positive ions outside the cell contributes to the negative resting membrane potential. A concentration gradient can also work in the opposite direction if there are more positive ions inside the cell and more negative ions outside the cell, however neurons usually have a negative concentration gradient (more negative ions inside the cell). 

Ions are constantly flowing in and out of the neuron trying to equalize their concentrations. However, the neuron has mechanisms to maintain the negative concentration gradient:
1. The neuron is very permeable to K+ ions so lots of K+ ions leak out (since there are more K+ inside the cell)
2. The neuron is slightly permeable to Na+ ions so some Na+ ions leak in (since there are more Na+ ions outside the cell)
3. To maintain the negative resting potential, the sodium-potassium pump pumps Na+ out of the cell and K+ back into the cell

Khan Academy. 2020. Neuron Action Potentials: The Creation Of A Brain Signal (Article) | Khan Academy. [online] Available at: https://www.khanacademy.org/test-prep/mcat/organ-systems/neuron-membrane-potentials/a/neuron-action-potentials-the-creation-of-a-brain-signal [Accessed 1 July 2020].

typeData.textContent:
The nervous system is composed of two basic cell types – glial cells and neurons. 

- Neuron Structure -
Membrane: semipermeable, allow small molecules and molecules without electrical charges to pass through
Dendrites: input site, receives signals from other neurons, dendritic spines display plasticity
Soma (cell body): signals received and transmitted electrically across soma
Axon: signals transmitted down to axon, extension from the soma
Myelin Sheath: formed by glial cells, coats the axon and acts as an insulator
Terminal Buttons: contain synaptic vesicles that have neurotransmitters

nodes.title: Cells of the Nervous System (Skye Shen)

typeData.textContent:
The human brain contains billions of neurons each connected with a large number of other neurons. Neurons are communicating with each other through electrochemical signals.

- Neuron Structure -
Membrane
semipermeable, allow small molecules and molecules without electrical charges to pass through

Dendrites
input site receives signals from other neurons, dendritic spines display plasticity

Soma (cell body)
signals received and transmitted electrically across soma

Axon
signals transmitted down to axon, extension from the soma

Myelin Sheath
formed by glial cells, coats the axon and acts as an insulator

Terminal Buttons
contain synaptic vesicles that have neurotransmitters 

The nervous system is composed of two basic cell types – glial cells and neurons. Neuron signal moves rapidly down the axon to their terminal buttons, where synaptic vesicles release neurotransmitters into the synapse. Once the neurotransmitters are released into the synapse, they travel and bind with corresponding receptors on the dendrites of the adjacent neurons.

- Neuron Communication - 
1. The neuron receives signals (neurotransmitters attached to the receptor)
2. Membrane opens, Na+ ions move into the cell
3. Internal charges become more positive, threshold of excitation has been reached
4. Neurons become more active -> action potential begins
5. More gates open, more Na+ moves in
6. Membrane potential increase until the peak action potential
7. Sodium gates close, potassium gates remain open
8. K+ ions leave, cells began repolarization
9. Potassium gates close slowly, cells hyperpolarized
10. Levels off, back to resting potential

This is an all-or-none situation - either sufficient or insufficient to reach the threshold. The signal moves from the cell body down to terminal buttons and there is no in-between. Excess neurotransmitters are drifted away - broken down into inactive fragments, pumped back to the presynaptic neurons.

nodes.title: Genes and environment regarding learning (Scott Weber)
nodes.description: I relate learning in different environments using the Cooper and Zubek study.

typeData.textContent:
Cooper and Zubek showed that the entire discussion should not be purely about the genes you already have. Tyron explored the idea of selective breeding to create the best maze running rat. Tryon’s experiment clearly shows that genes can influence the potential maze running ability of the rats. There is another side of the story however, the environment. Cooper and Zubek took the selectively bred rats and placed them into two environments, Impoverished and enriched. Environment definitely matters - they found important information about how the environment acts with natural potential. The maze dull rats from enriched environments outperformed (fewer maze errors) than maze dull from impoverished environments and, in fact they almost performed better than maze bright rats from impoverished environments. Additionally there is a much larger gap between maze bright and dull in the impoverished environment than enriched. As expected, maze bright rats in an enriched environment performed the best overall.

I believe that this experiment is very important applied to real life because it shows how the environment plays a moderately sized role in performance. This experiment shows that in the right environment someone can more easily maximize their potential. Applying this to real life in the sense of economic disparities the same premise makes sense. People with high socioeconomic status and funds, can afford to support and create a positive environment for their children. In a study looking at learning in kids with lower socioeconomic status found that “The findings of this study also reinforce the importance of teachers’ expectations of their students’ academic promise” (Barbarin 104). Just the expectations that the children were less able to learn was harmful. Different teaching loads and teacher inexperience were also linked to achievement. Teachers of low income areas were also more likely to be inexperienced (105). All these things come together to show that the environment that children are placed into does change how effective the learning they do is. Not only do lower socioeconomic children have a worse environment for learning, they are also less likely to be taught advanced material and they focus more on basic skills (103). This means that they will have to work even harder to get out of the current situation or they will be stuck. I believe that if we want to create change in poverty and educational disparities we need to invest more in schools and use studies like these. One way to break the loop is providing proper education to as many people as we can.

I had no idea before doing further research how different education can be for higher socioeconomic people. The idea that a teacher's perception of how a student will do also got me thinking about some of my highschool classes where I believed that the teacher thought I would not be able to do something. When we talk about socioeconomic status and creating change there are some many moving pieces but I think that it is important to look at one problem from many different perspectives to identify how to create a plan and move forward.

Bibliography:

Barbarin, Oscar A., and Nikki Aikens. “Overcoming the Educational Disadvantages of Poor Children: How Much Do Teacher Preparation, Workload, and Expectations Matter.” American Journal of Orthopsychiatry, vol. 85, no. 2, 2015, pp. 101–105., doi:10.1037/ort0000060.

typeData.textContent:
A human brain is divided by the longitudinal fissure into two hemispheres. Each half of the brain tends to develop specializations in certain cognitive functions: the left hemisphere is associated with analytical processes like language, math, and logic, whereas the right hemisphere specializes in artistic abilities like face recognition, spatial abilities, and musical understanding (Chulder, 2011). When one hemisphere has more significant control over certain functions, it is known as cerebral dominance. 

An entry from the Gale Encyclopedia (“Cerebral dominance,” 2020) states that the left hemisphere seems to be the overall dominant hemisphere in the majority of people. The entry explains that the motor area tends to be dominant in the left hemisphere, which explains why most people are right handed. Additionally, the entry states that in 95% of people, the left hemisphere is significantly larger with the Wernicke’s and Broca’s areas being more developed. This results in the left hemisphere being dominant in language functions. Interestingly, the entry also mentions that there is some evidence to suggest that a failure for one hemisphere to dominate language functions may lead to dyslexia in some individuals. 

The study of cerebral dominance has more practical effects when it comes to surgery and split-brain patients. For certain types of brain surgery it's important to identify which hemisphere is dominant for language functions; this is often done using the Wada test, where one half of the brain is aestheticized and then speech ability is tested (Chulder, 2011). If the language dominant hemisphere is aestheticized, the patient will no longer be able to speak (Chulder, 2011). When the corpus callosum is severed, the two hemispheres of the brain can no longer communicate, leading to split-brain syndrome that was described in the textbook. In split-brain patients cerebral dominance leads to a variety of interesting effects, such as when a stimulus is delivered to the non-language dominant hemisphere of the brain, the patient is unable to verbally describe the stimulus (Wolman, 2012). 

The brain has multiple functions that greatly differ throughout and demonstrates specializations in the two hemispheres. Medical studies and procedures throughout history have shown that cerebral dominance is prominent amongst the global population and affects daily activities, such as using a dominant hand, as well as the health of an individual when the brain is compromised. 

Sources

"Cerebral Dominance ." Gale Encyclopedia of Neurological Disorders. Retrieved June 22, 2020 from Encyclopedia.com: https://www.encyclopedia.com/science/encyclopedias-almanacs-transcripts-and-maps/cerebral-dominance  

Wolman, D. (2012, March 14). The split brain: A tale of two halves. Retrieved July 02, 2020, from https://www.nature.com/news/the-split-brain-a-tale-of-two-halves-1.10213

Chudler, E. H. (2011). One Brain...or Two? Retrieved July 02, 2020, from https://faculty.washington.edu/chudler/split.html

nodes.title: Cells of the Nervous System (Yilian Zhao)

typeData.textContent:
There are two types of cells that make up the Central Nervous system, called glia and neurons. Neurons are the main information processors, connected in order to perform all of the required actions for the nervous system to function. Glial cells function in a supportive role to neurons, insulating them by forming a myelin sheath, helping them connect properly, and disposing of waste products (Spielman, 2017, p. 80). There are multiple parts to a neuron; the soma has extensions called dendrites and contains the nucleus, the axon extends the soma to the terminal buttons, which have synaptic vesicles that contain neurotransmitters that are often released to receptors on other neurons. 

The synapse is the space between neurons into which the synaptic vesicles release neurotransmitters once the signal reaches the terminal buttons. The neurotransmitters bind to receptors on the other neuron, which they recognize due to the specific fit of a lock and key model (Spielman, 2017, p. 81). That is, the incorrect neurotransmitters cannot bind to certain receptors. Neurons are able to operate due to their semipermeable membrane, which allows certain ions to pass through and build up a difference in charge, which is then used to transmit signals. 

The imbalance in charge on either side of the membrane provides the energy for the signal to occur, which happens when neurotransmitter receptors receive their corresponding neurotransmitters and small pores open in the membrane of the neuron. These gates allow Na+ to come into the cell propelled by the concentration gradient since at resting state or resting potential, there is a buildup of more Na+ ions outside the cell, and more K+ ions inside the neuron (Spielman, 2017, p. 83). Once the pores open and Na+ flows in, the cells become more and more positive, and if the charge reaches the threshold of excitation, the action potential is able to commence, where sodium potassium pumps begin working to move K+ out of the cell and repolarize the cell to the original resting state. This signal is propelled from neuron to neuron until it reaches its destination. The way neurons communicate with each other is an electrochemical event, where the action potential going down an axon is electrical and the neurotransmitters travelling across the synapse is chemical.

nodes.title: The major glands of the endocrine system (Alex Huang)

typeData.textContent:
The glands of the endocrine system secrete a class of signaling molecules known as hormones; they are the chemical messengers of the body responsible for long-lasting, widespread regulation of virtually all the body's organ systems. Should these glands be defective, hormonal imbalances may result in physiological disorders within the body. Given the importance of these glands, let's delve into some of the significant glands and their respective hormonal outputs.

Starting with the "master gland" of the endocrine system; the pituitary gland otherwise known as the hypophysis sits nicely inside the skull at its base at an area known as the hypophyseal fossa. It contains both anterior and posterior (front and back) lobes attached to the hypothalamus through a stalk called the infundibulum (Doroudi, 2013). The messenger hormones secreted by the pituitary gland primarily regulate the other glands within the endocrine system, but there are some hormones such as growth hormones, pain-relieving endorphins, and blood pressure regulation. The overall regulation of hormones within the body is a synergy between the pituitary gland of the endocrine system and the hypothalamus of the CNS. In fact, it is the hypothalamus that commands the activity of the pituitary gland, secretes precursors its hormones, and in turn provides hormonal feedback as well. 

The pineal gland is also located in the brain; particularly in a narrow space known as a cerebral ventricle. The pineal gland secretes hormones responsible for regulating one's heartbeat and the distribution of melanin; a skin pigment. 

Below the brain at the neck, the thyroid gland sits between the trachea and the larynx. The hormones of the thyroid gland work to regulate appetite, growth, and crucially; metabolism. They also synergize with pea-shaped parathyroid glands situated behind the thyroid gland to regulate blood calcium levels based on feedback from calcium levels present in the blood.  It should be noted that too much or too little thyroid gland secretions can have detrimental physiological implications. For instance, Grave's disease occurs when the excess secretion of a hormone called thyroxine results in agitation, weight loss, and bulging eyes. This is also known as hyperthyroidism. Conversely, hypothyroidism can also occur when insufficient levels of thyroid hormones can cause symptoms in suffering individuals such as tiredness and a feeling of coldness. Thyroid disorders can, fortunately, be remedied with medicines that balance the thyroid hormone levels back to healthy levels. 

Adrenal glands are located at the top of the kidneys. These glands consist of 2 parts; a cortex and a medulla. The cortex is the outside layer and is responsible for secreting hormones that help balance out sodium and glucose levels (Doroudi, 2013). Meanwhile, the medulla is the inner layer of the glands. The medulla secretes the stress relief hormones like epinephrine and norepinephrine, you may know them as adrenaline and noradrenaline respectively. Another neat feature about the medulla of the adrenal glands is that instead of receiving commands through nerve cells, cells inside the medulla actually act AS the nerve cells that receive signals from the sympathetic nerves from the nervous system to secrete epinephrine and norepinephrine. These cells are known as chromaffin cells. (Doroudi, 2013.)

Besides glands, there are other organs and structure which also secrete regulatory hormones. For instance, the pancreas secretes hormones like glucagon and insulin that balance blood sugar by increasing and decreasing levels respectively. 

Additionally, sex hormones are primarily secreted and controlled by the gonads; testicles in males and ovaries in females respectively. Testicles secrete testosterone, and the ovaries secrete estrogen and progesterone.

I'm having technical issues attaching my H5P video to this node. I'm working hard to resolve it.
My H5P video is #355

The central nervous system (CNS) controls most functions of the body and mind. It consists of two parts: the brain and the spinal cord. The spinal cord is the highway for communication between the body and the brain. When the spinal cord is injured, the exchange of information between the brain and other parts of the body is disrupted. 
The spinal cord functions primarily in the transmission of nerve signals from the motor cortex to the body, and from the afferent fibers of the sensory neurons to the sensory cortex. It is also a center for coordinating many reflexes and contains reflex arcs that can independently control reflexes. It is also the location of groups of spinal interneurons that make up the neural circuits known as central pattern generators. These circuits are responsible for controlling motor instructions for rhythmic movements such as walking.
The spinal cord is the main pathway for information connecting the brain and peripheral nervous system. Much shorter than its protecting spinal column, the human spinal cord originates in the brainstem, passes through the foramen magnum, and continues through to the conus medullaris near the second lumbar vertebra before terminating in a fibrous extension known as the filum terminale.

Vertebrae and spinal disks
The front part of each of the vertebrae is called the vertebral body. There are 23 elastic spinal disks between the vertebrae – except for between the skull and the first cervical vertebra, and between the first and second cervical vertebrae. The sacrum and the tailbone can't be moved, and are made up only of bone.
The disks have a solid, multi-layered casing of cartilage fiber and a gel-like core. They keep the spine flexible so that we can lean over and rotate our upper body. They also absorb shocks that are transferred to the spine when we run or jump, for instance.
When we put pressure on our spine, the spinal disks release fluid and become thinner ("compress"); when the pressure is relieved, they absorb fluid and become thicker ("decompress"). Because we usually put more pressure on our spine during the day and relieve the pressure at night, we are around 1.5 to 2 centimeters shorter by the end of the day. Over many years our spine starts to wear, meaning that as we age our spinal disks become thinner, the vertebrae become compressed and the spine curves more. That is why we usually "shrink" a little (a few centimeters) as we age.

nodes.title: Natural Selection of Sickle-Cell Anaemia (Megan Ho)

typeData.textContent:
Sickle-cell anaemia is an autosomal recessive disease, which means it can only be inherited when both parents carry the defective gene. When an individual has sickle-cell anaemia, their red blood cells are mutated from a regular round shape to an abnormal crescent-moon shape. Sickled red blood cells can clog blood vessels and result in various physiological problems, such as intense fevers, chess pains, and damage to bone due to lack of oxygen supply. Individuals with sickle-cell anaemia usually die at an early age. 

According to natural selection, traits that increase an individual’s chances of survival are more likely to be passed onto future generations. Given that individuals diagnosed with sickle-cell anaemia typically do not live long enough to reproduce, the likelihood of inheriting the defective gene gradually decreases over time. In most parts of the world, such as in North American and European countries, this form of natural selection can be observed, whereby individuals with the sickle-cell defective gene are selected against. However, in places like Africa and Southeast Asia, individuals with the sickle-cell gene are actually selected for. As mentioned earlier, sickle-cell anaemia is an autosomal recessive disorder, which means that individuals carrying one copy of the sickle cell gene do not suffer from the disease. In fact, these individuals have a selective advantage, because carrying the sickle-cell gene results in immunity to malaria, a lethal disease common in tropical climates. Being immune to malaria, these carrier individuals have increased fitness, and by natural selection, this results in a higher chance of survival and passing their genes to their offspring. Thus, in tropical areas where malaria is prevalent, the sickle cell gene is still commonly detected in populations. 

References 
Luzzatto, Lucio. “Sickle Cell Anaemia And Malaria.” Mediterranean Journal of Hematology and Infectious Diseases, vol. 4, no. 1, 2012, doi:10.4084/mjhid.2012.065.

nodes.title: New Approach to Nature-Nurture Dichotomy (Megan Ho)

typeData.textContent:
The nature-nurture dichotomy is an ongoing debate that reflects on the importance of genes and environmental factors on the development of behaviour. Nature refers to genetic contributions that are inherited from ancestors, while nurture refers to environmental factors, such as wealth and education level, which can continuously change over an individual's lifetime. 

For the longest time, psychologists and behaviourists have attempted to attribute behaviour to either one of genetics or the environment. For example, consider the intelligence of identical twins. Identical twins are 100% genetically similar, and given that they come from the same family, they would have relatively similar living and learning conditions. However, even with seemingly constant nature and nurture factors, it is not impossible for these twins to have drastically different levels of intelligence. In these cases, instead of trying to pin-point whether intelligence is affected by genes or the environment, it would be more useful to take into account the contributions of both nature and nurture to an individual's behaviour, and then rate the level of contributions between the two. 

The new approach to the nature-nurture dichotomy looks at individuals as groups, rather than at a single individual. It considers what proportion of the difference between individuals within these groups is due to differences between genetic inheritances, and what proportion of the difference between individuals within these groups is due to differences between environmental conditions. Looking at the identical twin example again, we can access the differences in mental and physical health between the twins, and then effectively evaluate how much of this different is due to inborn factors, and how much is due to other non-genetic factors. This new way of dealing with the nature-nurture dichotomy also allows for the use of a heritability estimate, which is a descriptive statistic that calculates how much of variability between individuals is due to genetic variation.

nodes.title: Why is our resting membrane potential at -70 mV? (Yanbo Li)
nodes.description: There are actually five reasons. Can you successfully infer what all these five reasons are?

typeData.textContent:
4 factors for unequal distribution of ions (aka 4 reasons of resting membrane potential)

1. It is because of differential permeability (due to the presence of sodium ion channels). Sodium ion channels are resistant to the passage of sodium ions. By contrast, the potassium ion channels offer little resistance to the passage of potassium. 

2. Ions move down their concentration gradients. Na+ hard to enter; K+ move out easily.

3. The negative internal (net) charge creates pressure for both Na+ and K+ to enter the cell (electrostatic pressure). Despite these two sorts of pressures on sodium ions, few of them actually enter the cell (neural membrane largely impermeable to Na+ at resting potential).

4. Sodium-potassium pump transports 3 Na+ out for every 2 K+ it transports in. Few Na+ that manage to enter the cell are removed by ion transporter in the membrane, and the pump consumes cellular energy.

5. Chloride ions & negatively charged proteins contribute to negative net charge in cytoplasm (inside) and positive net charge outside.

typeData.textContent:
What are voltage-gated ion channels?

Voltage-gated ion channels are transmembrane proteins that are regulated by changes in the electrical membrane potential close to the channel. These proteins play an important role in cell excitability, neurons, muscles, and secretory cells. When these channels open, they allow ions to move across an electrochemical gradient of the cellular membranes.

How do voltage-gated ion channels open?

Voltage-gated ion channels open when membrane depolarization occurs. These channels tend to be closed at resting potential, but upon detecting a change in electric membrane potential they open. These channels respond to specific positive and negative ions including sodium, potassium, calcium, and chlorine. 

Axonal Electrical Transmission

A number of voltage-gated ion channels play a role in axonal electrical transmission. The major determinants are voltage-gated ion channels that are selective for sodium and potassium. These two channels are necessary for the conduction of action potentials. Action potentials are necessary for neurons to send information down an axon, from the cell body. A voltage-gated ion channel opens when the membrane potential reaches threshold. 

Rasband, M. N., & Trimmer, J. S. (2009) Ion Channel Localization in Axons. In Encyclopedia of Neuroscience.

While Charles Darwin was not the first to think of evolution, he did create large amounts of evidence supporting the idea. In modern times, there are a number of diverse fields of evidence supporting the theory of evolution from bones to embryo development, some going beyond the evidence Darwin first came up with. 

Part of the evidence from the bones of living beings is the similarities in some types of animals. Mammals, for example, have similar bones, though it may not seem like it at first. The wings of a bat are in the same area as your fingers and have the same basic bone structure. The pattern of bones are the same in both bats and humans, although bat "fingers" are much larger compared to the rest of the body. Whale fin bones are also the same order. Mammals  have the same general structure of bones, just modified for different purposes, such as swimming, running, or flying. 

	Another piece of evidence is the existence of vestigial structures. Vestigial structures are parts of the body that serve little to no purpose, but might have served a function in ancestral species of the animals. One example is a leg bone in a whale, which remains inside the body of the whale its whole life. While it is not useful for the whale, it was useful for when its ancestors walked on land. 

	A surprising piece of evidence for evolution is found in the development of embryos. In frogs, the embryos pass through a larval stage in the, with features of normally aquatic larvae. However, they hatch ready to live on land, suggesting an ancestral species that had a larval stage. 

	Supporting evidence for evolution also came up in geography. In the past, the continents were arranged in a different pattern than they are today, such as South America and Africa being connected. This leads to a single species of animal or plant being able to exist on multiple continents, and then become different species after the continents split, should evolution be true. As that is what we see, evolution gets more supporting evidence. 

	You can learn more about misconceptions of evolution in "Common misconceptions of evolution by Hary Chae." Another interesting part of evolution is courtship displays, which help the creation of new species by creating a barrier between groups.  More information on those can be found in “Mating in the animal world: Examples of Courtship displays by Harry.” A quiz about epigenetics can be found in “transgenerational epigenetics quiz (Navin Johal)”


Bibliography

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evidence_of_common_descent

nodes.title: The Myelin Sheath (Samantha Chiang)
nodes.description: A brief summary of the function of the myelin sheath and a simple breakdown of multiple sclerosis.

typeData.textContent:
The myelin sheath plays an integral role in the nervous system. The fatty substance can typically be found along axons and functions as an insulator. This property is important as it helps increase the speed of neuronal signal transmission. 

As action potential is propagated down a unmyelinated axon, it is repeatedly regenerated at each sodium channel along its path. This unique behavior is responsible for the “all or none” nature of action potential. In myelinated axons, signal transmission occurs in a similar way; action potential is still regenerated at each sodium channel. However, in myelinated axons, regeneration of the action potential only occurs in the special unmyelinated gaps between myelin sheaths called the “Nodes of Ranvier”, where sodium channels are particularly concentrated. The insulation of the axon effectively allows the signal to “jump” from one node to the next, thereby speeding up the rate of signal transmission. 

Deterioration of the myelin sheath can severely impair normal function of the nervous system. The autoimmune disease multiple sclerosis is one example of the damaging effects of demyelination. In multiple sclerosis, the myelin sheath is attacked and broken down by the immune system. This large-scale loss of insulation interferes with the nervous system’s ability to transmit signals. This can manifest as a dizziness, fatigue, loss of balance, and sexual dysfunction among many other symptoms. 

While there is currently no known cure for multiple sclerosis, a variety of treatments exist to help individuals cope with symptoms of the disease. Physical therapy can help individuals adapt to their mobility restrictions. Muscle relaxants and medications to treat fatigue, energy, depression (such as selective serotonin-reuptake inhibitors), or nerve inflammation can also be prescribed to address symptoms. 

References
OpenStax College. (2017). Psychology. Houston, TX: OpenStax CNX. Retrieved from https://openstax.org/details/books/psychology

Multiple sclerosis. (2020, June 12). Retrieved from https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/multiple-sclerosis/diagnosis-treatment/drc-20350274

nodes.title: Fighting Multiple Sclerosis (Darren Tsang)
nodes.description: Fighting Multiple Sclerosis

typeData.textContent:
Myelin is a fatty layer that wraps around axons. It helps action potentials be conducted more quickly along axons. This is why myelin is so important and diseases such as multiple sclerosis, which attacks and destroys myelin, can be tremendously disabling. Multiple sclerosis can cause nerve damage all throughout your body. This means it can cause damage from the top, such as impairing your vision, all the way to the bottom, such as affecting your balance on your feet. Currently there is no cure to multiple sclerosis.

Myelin can be created by your body using glial cells. In the peripheral nervous system, schwann cells are responsible for myelinating axons. In the central nervous system, it is oligodendrocytes that does this job. Because of this, one way that researchers have been looking to try to help people with multiple sclerosis is by finding ways to promote oligodendrocytes to repair myelin more quickly. One of these ways is by using thyroid hormones. However, this could not be a possible solution because increased exposure to these hormones can have serious side effects on one's heart, bones, and muscles. Recently, a compound called sobetirome seems to promote remyelination without any of the side effects that comes along with using thyroid hormones. It will take time for further research and testing to be conducted.

 Although scientists are still trying to find a cure for multiple sclerosis, there are already multiple medications that can be prescribed to help treat the disease. You can learn more about some of the medications that can help treat multiple sclerosis by taking a look at my flashcards!

Works Cited

Grey, H. (2020, June 08). New MS Treatments. Retrieved July 09, 2020, from https://www.healthline.com/health/multiple-sclerosis/new-research-treatments

[Neuroscientifically Challenged]. (2011, September 15). 2-Minute Neuroscience: Myelin [Video file]. Retrieved from https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5V7RZwDpmXE

Oregon Health & Science University. (2019, April 18). Study shows promise in repairing damaged myelin: Potential 'game-changer' for people with multiple sclerosis. ScienceDaily. Retrieved July 8, 2020 from www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2019/04/190418141614.htm

Epigenetic Therapy for Cancer Treatment (Cindy Hsu) [brainfreeze]

typeData.textContent:
Cancer was originally thought of as a genetic disease, with the root of the disease being its direct damage to cell DNA. More recently, cancer has been discovered to have both genetic and epigenetic components (“Epigenetic Therapy”, 2007), although the mixture depends on the specific cancer type. 

Epigenetics is the study of the expression of information in genes (i.e. a person's phenotype), which can change without the underlying gene sequence changing. A person's epigenetics can change throughout their lifetime through biological processes such as DNA methylation and histone modification, which are caused by environmental exposure, choice of diet, and other lifestyle factors. These epigenetic changes also accumulate over a person's life as a possible byproduct of cell division.

This mention of cell division is especially critical in relation to cancer. Although harmful epigenetic changes are a component in other diseases such as diabetes and asthma (Kelly, Theresa K, et al., 2010), cancer causes accelerated and uncontrolled cell growth which allows these epigenetic changes to accumulate faster than they would have through natural aging. According to a study by Kelly et al. in 2010, cancer also causes a global loss in DNA methylation levels. One avenue of epigenetic therapy that is being explored is the possibility of reverting epigenetic changes in cancer-affected cells, in order to restore their normal function without having to resort to more extreme solutions (“Epigenetic Therapy”, 2007).

Chemotherapy, one of the most common forms of cancer treatment, relies on using strong doses of drugs to kill cancerous cells. These drugs often cause unwanted side effects in the patient (e.g. hair loss), as other rapidly dividing cells also become targets despite being non-cancerous. Over time, patients can also develop resistance to these drugs. Thus, other forms of epigenetic treatment focus on using epigenetics in combination with other methods, such as by improving the effectiveness of chemotherapy by increasing responsiveness (Kelly, Theresa K, et al., 2010). 

Epigenetic therapy has successfully been used to treat cancers that affect the blood, bone marrow, or lymph nodes, through two specific FDA-approved treatments (Kelly, Theresa K, et al., 2010). There has been little success in using this method against solid cancers (tumors), but as the treatment method is still relatively new, there is still much to be studied.

Sources

“Epigenetic Therapy.” PBS, PBS, 16 Oct. 2007, www.pbs.org/wgbh/nova/article/epigenetic-therapy/.

Hellebrekers, Debby, and Manon van Engeland. “Epigenetic Therapy.” SpringerLink, Springer Nature, 10 Mar. 2017, link.springer.com/referenceworkentry/10.1007/978-3-642-16483-5_1948.

Kelly, Theresa K, et al. “Epigenetic Modifications as Therapeutic Targets.” Nature Biotechnology, vol. 28, no. 10, Oct. 2010, pp. 1069–1078., doi:10.1038/nbt.1678.

nodes.title: The Study of Nature vs. Nurture

typeData.textContent:
Although we have now learned that our genes and our environment equally effect each other to determine a person’s characteristics and/or behaviour. It is still a very fascinating idea especially when you look at both Nature and Nurture individually and not combined.

I think we have all, at some point in our lives, heard ‘you’re just naturally smart’ or ‘it’s in your genetics’. This is an example of the nature argument that was widely supported by European Ethologists. Plato and Descartes were both believers that our characteristics are solely inherited and cannot be learned or taught by the environment that we live in. However, North American Behaviorists argued the contrary with John Locke stating that humans are ‘blank slates’ when we are born and and ‘everything that we are and all of our knowledge is determined by our experience’ (Cherry, 2020) meaning our characteristics are solely dependent on the environment in which we were raised and the people around us who influenced us.

The most common studies that have been done to solidify each sides arguments have been twin studies. Both monozygotic and dizygotic twins are centered around the nature vs nurture studies as monozygotic twins are twins who share the 100% of the same genes (split from one egg), whereas dizygotic twins are twins who share 50% of the same genes (two separate eggs). Studies tend to research the IQ of monozygotic twins when they were reared apart from birth into two different home environments (one more wealthy and the other less well off) and compare their IQ’s to determine if there were any differences which would indicate an effect of nurture. Another popular study studies dizygotic twin participants in the same household and compare their IQ’s to determine if genes were the cause of these differences.

Bibliography

Cherry, Kendra. “What to Know About Nature vs. Nurture.” Verywell Mind, 2020, www.verywellmind.com/what-is-nature-versus-nurture-2795392.

nodes.title: Anatomy of a Typical Synapse (Alyssa Juma)
Gender in Nature vs. Nurture (Evelyn Sun)

typeData.textContent:
There has long been a debate about whether gender was constructed through nurture or nature. Psychologist John Money is a strong proponent of the "gender neutrality theory."
He believed that children were born without gender differences, and their cognition of gender almost all came from the acquired environment and education. If children are "gender redistributed" at an early age and properly cultivated, they can all get rid of their original gender. Therefore, he once made an experiment about gender reassignment on a boy named Bruce, who lost his penis in a cauterization. His testicles were cut off, fitted with a woman's vulva, and renamed Brenda. Also, their parents were instructed not to tell Brenda the truth that she was born a boy in order to reshape her cognition. Brenda also had a twin brother named Brian with the same genes and the environment who could be a perfect control group. 

After the gender reassignment, Money observed his progress regularly and gave Brenda a series of "nurture" to help her understand her gender, which including telling her about the differences between men and women by taking nude photos of her and her brother and letting two children have sexual rehearsal play which is very brutal and controversial. When the twins were nine years old, Money declared the case a success as "John and Joan case”, and he concluded that gender is determined by nurture, not by nature because, for the first few years, her parents pointed out that Brenda was indeed more feminine, cleaner and less messy than her brother, also Brenda had no idea she was born a boy. 

However, more negative details were eliminated in Money’s report. Brenda actually didn’t feel like a girl, and she was isolated and bullied by her peers. Her brother Brian was later diagnosed with schizophrenia. After Brenda’s parents told her the fact of gender reassignment, she decided to live as a man, changed her name to David, and did gender-reassignment surgery back to male. However, in the last years of David's life, there were multiple shocks and pressures. Brian died from taking too many antidepressants, and David died at the age of 38 by shooting himself in the head with a truncated shotgun.

nodes.title: Is Bullying Genetic? (Lang Kuoch)
nodes.description: A Closer Look at the Nature vs. Nurture Debate of Bullying in the Workplace

typeData.textContent:
As we continue to deepen our understanding of human behaviour through the lens of psychology, we learn more and more about how our behaviour is influenced by a variety of factors. Our most recent understanding regarding the Nature vs. Nurture debate of behaviour strongly suggests that both nature and nurture play a role in human behaviour. So, what does this mean for bullying, a behaviour we so often relate to the mean kid on the school playground? While the environmental origins of bullying behaviours may not come as a surprise to you, there has been evidence found to suggest that the aggressiveness in bullies is partly genetic as well. Harvey et al., in their 2009 article “Bullying in the 21st Century Global Organization: An Ethical Perspective” take a deeper dive into the hidden mechanics behind bullies in the adult workplace.

This article seeks to unravel the mystery behind the nature, or bullying behaviour influenced by the innate genetic make-up of an individual, and the nurture, the learned behaviours from environments allowing bullying to perpetuate. Bullying is often a misunderstood, misdiagnosed, and a mismanaged behaviour in work environments (Harvey et al., 2009).  Although we all have some idea of what a bully is, to take a closer look at this scientifically, we have to come up with a precise, consistent, and accurate definition. Luckily, we already have one:

Bullying is repeated acts and practices that are directed at one or more workers, which are unwanted by the victim(s), which may be done deliberately or unconsciously, but clearly cause humiliation, offence, and distress, and may interfere with job performance and/or cause unpleasant working environment (Einarsen, 1999, p. 17)

Bullying can manifest in a variety of actions or behaviours. In the work environment, bullying can fall into one of five categories: 1) Name calling by a bully in public; 2) Using a scapegoat by placing the fault for failure on a stigmatized individual or group in the organization; 3) Increasing work pressure to perform on one individual/group beyond the level of expectations of others in the organization; 4) Sexual harassment of coworkers generally by individuals with a power differential; 5) Physical abuse or harm to a stigmatized individual or group (Harvey et al., 2009). 

The Nature of Bullying

Contrary to intuition, there is strong evidence that supports the idea that there may be natural “causes” that play a role in one taking on bullying tendencies. Such causes appear to center on gene defects and the absorption of essential hormones in the brain. In fact, the contention that there is a biological connection between inherited characteristics and aggression is supported by numerous longitudinal studies. Although Harvey et al. make no claim that with its biological markers that bullying is predestined, they posit that there is a “strong connection between inherited genes and the propensity for individuals to become aggressive in certain environmental contexts” (2009). In sum, there appear to be three leading biological influences on the propensity to exhibit aggression behaviour: 1) Brain Related Issues. Individuals with pathological, antisocial, and aggressive behaviours exhibit significantly lower uptake of glucose in the prefrontal cortex, an area of the brain generally associated with self-control, maturity, judgement, reasoning, and aggression; 2) Mutation of Specific Genes. Impulsive, aggressive males often have a malfunctioning gene which usually codes for an enzyme called monoamine oxidase A (MAOA). This gene metabolizes serotonin, dopamine, and norepinephrine. The mutation can cause the gene to metabolize unbalanced levels of these chemicals, leading to high levels of aggression and antisocial behaviour; 3) Overly developed immune system. Interestingly, there seems to be a strong correlation with individuals who display aggressive behaviour and who have a strong immune system with aggression-associated immunity association strongest for CD4 cells and B-lymphocytes.
Although these markers for aggressive and bullying behaviour can be observed, we must remember that there is minimum certainty to the prediction of it; that is to say, individuals with these conditions do not automatically become bullies (Harvey et al., 2009). Instead, the increasing occurrence of bullying in the workplace is primarily attributed to environmental conditions, which may manifest through a variety of factors, such as deficiences in work design (lack of or improper supervision, or environments conducive to allow bullying), deficiencies in leadership behaviour (lack of training or management on how to address bullying), a socially exposed position of the victim (abuse of power differentials in the workplace), and low morale standard in the department (workplace culture and climate held to low standards, where bullying is not only tolerated, but expected). It can also arise due to learned antisocial behaviours from childhood or as an imitation of aggression experience in home or in other areas in life.

In short, like most human behaviours, both genes and environment play an intricate role in determining if someone will exhibit bullying behaviours in their life. However, this may just complicate how you feel about someone who may be aggressive, unkind, and antagonizing in your life: if it is in their genes, how does this change, if at all, how we interact and deal with the people like this in our lives?


Works Cited:

Michael Harvey, D. T. (2009). Bullying in the 21st Century Global Organization: An Ethical Perspective. Journal of Business Ethics, 27-40.

nodes.title: The 4 requirements for Natural Selection (Amir Hosseini)

typeData.textContent:
As presented in week 7, lecture 2,  natural selection is one of the main contributors of evolution on this planet. Natural selection acts as a filter that only allows certain traits to pass through, hence pass on and reproduce. Natural selection occurs when individuals with advantageous traits reproduce and pass on their genes, and species without those traits face difficulty surviving. Those traits are what affects the biological fitness of species, species with the advantageous trait are more likely to survive and mate, yet species without those traits fail to survive and reproduce; thus, having a lower biological fitness. However, there are four requirements that Darwin found critical for natural selection to take place.

Firstly, the organisms in the population must vary in traits to allow natural selection to take place. For instance, looking at a population of birds, there must be variations in size or colour for natural selection to occur. Variability in traits leads to variability in fitness, which leads to selection.

Secondly, such traits must be heritable, meaning they can be passed on. For natural selection to occur, genes of specific characteristics must be passed on to future generations, thus evolving the particular specie.

Thirdly, there must be a variation in survival rates (competition). Meaning that species must compete to survive, thus certain traits will become advantageous to those who carry the genes for it; hence they will have higher biological fitness, thus survive and reproduce.

Lastly, the individuals with the advantageous trait must adapt to the environment and survive and reproduce. Those individuals cannot be a random sample of the population, meaning that they must make up the population. 

Source:
Freeman, S., Harrington, M., & Sharp, J. (2014). Biological science. Toronto: Pearson.

nodes.title: What is the role of epigenetics modifications in shaping twins’ behavior? (Mayra)

typeData.textContent:
Welcome to the last section of this week’s tapestry. In this node, we will learn about the interactions of genes with the environment. 
Gene-environment interaction is when two different genotypes respond to environmental variation in different ways. Studying gene-environment interaction is important for improving accuracy and precision in the assessment of genetic and environmental influences (Ottman, 2008). The current scientific opinion towards the nature vs. nurture debate is that all traits are influenced by both genetic and environmental differences, neither genetic differences nor environmental differences are the only cause of phenotypic variation (Koehl, 2015). They work together that “our genes influence our environment, and our environment influences the expression of our genes” (Spielman, et al., 2018, pp. 78-79).
Now I will introduce one example that shows gene-environment interaction.



References:

Koehl, M. (2015). Gene-environment interaction in programming hippocampal plasticity: Focus on adult neurogenesis. Frontiers in Molecular Neuroscience, 8:41. doi:10.3389/fnmol.2015.00041

Ottman, R. (2008). Gene-Environment Interaction: Definitions and Study Designs [Abstract]. Nature Precedings. doi:10.1038/npre.2008.2653.1

Spielman, R. M., Dumper, K., Jenkins, W., Lacombe, A., Lovett, M., & Perlmutter, M. (2018). Psychology (pp. 78-79). Houston, TX: OpenStax, Rice University.

nodes.title: Phylogenies: How we sketch the Tree of Life (Tyrone Ly)
nodes.description: Phylogenies: How we sketch the Tree of Life

typeData.textContent:
In this week’s lecture, we were introduced to a tree-like (or bush-like) diagram which is comprised by a wide variety of organisms, ranging from the simplest to the most complex form. In fact, this model does not only demonstrate the knowledge of biodiversity but also summarizes the evolution of all species that inhabit the Earth in a well-organized chronological order. It is a phylogeny, or in other words, a phylogenetic tree.

          By definition, phylogenies are visual representations for the hypotheses of how different species are related to each other through inheritance and evolution from a common ancestor (Baum, 2008). They were developed as an appreciation for Darwin’s Theory of Evolution, and indeed evolutionary biologists have been using them since the time of Darwin. However, before our scientists finally arrived at the consensus of “tree thinking”, many models have been proposed as explanations for the evolution of species, including a well-known one, which you may have been able to guess, the “ladder of life” (Baum, 2008).

          Ladder models were introduced with a belief that humans are the most advanced species of all kinds, and the degree of perfection gradually increases along the ladder from the most primitive to its peak where mankind stands. According to Dr. Baum (2008), though this misleading viewpoint was firmly rejected by many biologists and even by Darwin, it is still existing amongst our daily life owing largely to the media, whose knowledge of evolutionary biology is undeniably limited. 

           The aforementioned reason is why phylogenies are common mostly to the intellectuals, such as scientists or university students, but not the general public. Despite this, reading and interpreting phylogenies are critical skills that require practice, and surprisingly a rigorous understanding of these diagrams have only been developed over the past few decades (Baum, 2008). We, as students, would have easily misinterpreted the concepts of evolution through the use of phylogenies without prior knowledge of how they work. 

           These trees can have several appearances, which ranges from V-shaped, U-shaped, circular, to the bush-like diagram as in lecture, etc. To understand phylogenies, we can think of them as zoomed-out versions of numerous pedigrees (Baum, 2008), which are charts used for tracking the inheritance of phenotypes within families or populations. As long as there is gene flow between certain populations, they will be grouped together to form a branch (or lineage) on the grand tree. Thus, where a branch splits is where evolution has occurred and the difference in genotype between the new populations continues to increase over the course of time, leading to the emergence of new species. 

          Over billions of years of evolution, many species have come to existence as of nowadays, and nevertheless many have also come to extinction. Each of them is represented by either a formerly produced or a new budding twig on the tree, and as Darwin have said, “[T]he Tree of Life … covers the earth with ever-branching and beautiful ramifications” (Baum, 2008).


References
Baum, D. (2008) Reading a Phylogenetic Tree: The Meaning of Monophyletic Groups. Nature Education 1(1):190, https://www.nature.com/scitable/topicpage/reading-a-phylogenetic-tree-the-meaning-of-41956/ 
Baum, D. (2008) Trait evolution on a phylogenetic tree: Relatedness, similarity, and the myth of evolutionary advancement. Nature Education 1(1):191, https://www.nature.com/scitable/topicpage/trait-evolution-on-a-phylogenetic-tree-relatedness-41936/
